name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: The luxury industry is coming back strong but clearly with growth rates of 33% at Hermes & 37% at Louis Vuitton/ Dior, the highest brands are where the action is.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Hermes Q1 sales +33%(!) on 2019 pre-pandemic levels blowing past street. Top tier luxury is just flying. $LVMH $EL

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @ToddSullivan @BobBrinker Sure but your point was comparing first dose performance. No fan of the UK government’s oVerall Covid performance but it’s been a home run on vaccines, and remember UK is importing vaccines.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @ToddSullivan @BobBrinker UK is close to fully vaccinating only over 70s. Everyone else is receiving single doses only for now. And about to cross 50% of total population, not just adults.  https://t.co/nVnRW5nUH3

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @BobBrinker @ToddSullivan 63% of adult population in UK

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This is a very strong report all round, with high ticket categories very strong. But even with 're-opening' & easy comparisons, web at +29% still gaining share. $XRT $AMZN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Covid comparisons help but March US retail sales a whopping +27% y/y. DIY, electronics furniture, sporting goods (all Covid winners) very strong. Apparel finally showing strength +100% $XRT $BBY $HD $LOW $WSM $URBN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: 4% pricing at Frito, 5% pricing at Pepsi & Quaker. $PEP, $PG & $KO demonstrating incredible pricing power in the US during pandemic. PS duopolies/monopolies help!

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Top tier luxury is crushing it. The likes of $CPRI, Burberry etc are picking up crumbs as a rising tide floats all boats. Good enough for depressed share prices but Hermes, Cartier, LV & Chanel are really where it’s really at.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Vs pre-pandemic 2019 levels, $LVMH US +15% & Asia +26%. Europe -18% but with zero Chinese tourism implies spending by wealthy Europeans up 40%+. Wowzer.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Booze, watches jewelry up vs 2019 in Q1 2021 at $LVMH. Despite Europe lockdown. Only beauty down & $LVMH again lost a ton of market share there. $EL #Cartier #Hermes

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $LVMH Q1 fashion/leather sales +37% on 2019 levels. Read that again, 2019 not 2020. The pandemic has been boomtime for luxury. $EL $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: That doesn’t diminish that both $WSM & $RH are in a sweetspot that is both bigger & longer lasting than most had thought. But clearly very different communication styles relative to delivery

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This was a very good $RH Q. But as always, Gary talks a greater game than he delivers in contrast to Laura Alber at $WSM. 36% ‘core’ demand became +22% sales, actually lower than +25% y/y at $WSM.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Pottery Barn’s latest email, focusing squarely on sustainability. Clearly working as a great differentiator for them. $WSM  https://t.co/R0yC8GnEq2

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Probably coincidental but on heels of blowout $WSM Q where it highlighted benefits of its free design services, $RH sends out this email today!  https://t.co/QvbHDMJdeT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Would have liked $WSM CEO to be a bit less bullish & stick to her usual talking a good game & delivering a great one, but heck this Q was a beauty. And making it clear that its stores will help $WSM participate in the 're-opening' trade.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Great to see caring for employees (only major retailer to pay employees in shuttered stores throughout pandemic) richly rewarded by shoppers. $WSM

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Burberry sees Q1 comp +28-32% vs -27% in COVID-hit Q from year ago. Only slightly down from 2019. Even second tier luxury is joining the party $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Despite vast customer bases, difficulty in deploying deposits due to lack of expertise has meant retailer banks have not been the home run most expected. Some of my thoughts in @FT with thanks to @rbrtrmstrng $WMT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Urban in one breath tells you to be excited Q1 sales will match pre-COVID levels & then adds gross margins will fall ‘several hundred’ basis points. The under-achievement of many of these ‘visionary’ ‘digital-leading’ businesses is epic. $URBN $JWN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: When industry inventory is super tight & promos are non-existent, Nordstrom somehow manages to find itself in an overstocked position & needing to discount to clear. Superbly done. $JWN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke This feels like the usual smack the Covid winner buy the trash trade. Fretting about $4 billion in capex makes a catchy headline but the market's just looking for an excuse to sell these names.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @space_menagerie Haven't looked at it in detail, but BBW is fantastic. And it seems to be holding comp even as the sanitiser craze normalises. Amazing to think this used to the much smaller part of the $LB businesses!

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: A&F boasts of 'transformed' model with digital at 54% of sales. Reality is store sales tumbled $1 billion while online rose sub $500 million. What excuses will these companies use when store sales normalise & these exaggerated ratios fall back? $ANF $M $JWN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Again I don’t think we’re in a very different place. What $TGT achieved was brilliant too eso in contrast to $WMT. Not taking that away from them

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Grocery no? A huge benefit from stocking up to start with & adding stuff alongside. A year is a long time but from memory only apparel was weak to start with

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Yes $TGT added scale to a web model that was already there. But it got a huge benefit from staying open in all sorts of categories like home, toys, apparel when it’s direct competitors couldn’t

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Nah. Don’t agree with that take. The sheer scale of seeing store models shift to delivering scale online was simply wowzer. Not to take credit away from $TGT but likes of $BBY & $DKS basically built a massive web biz / store pick up from nothing

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Sure they didn't just rest on their laurels. But the ones that deserve the most credit IMHO are folks like $BBY $DKS & $WSM who got there despite being forced to close stores.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Sure. But Covid winners like $HD $KR $LOW $TGT $WMT $DG all got huge boosts from being allowed to open when others were closed.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke In all fairness, Jeff with a little help from Uncle Sam...

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @RationalResear But we're re-opening! It's all going to be great!

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @drexmaven Well it’s been a monster for quite some time. This is pretty much the uncertainty of how it will comp & this ongoing excitement with everything beaten up by COVID

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: One point of weakness in Depot - both margin & cash flow not as strong as usual. Inventory grew far less than sales at +14% y/y. In all likelihood a reflection of a better much in-stock position $HD $LOW $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Depot isn't giving guidance & of course no one knows. But it does achieve the flat outcome it is suggesting or even some way shy of that, that is one helluva share gain over two years. Something no one really foresaw $HD $LOW $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Covid winners continue to best everyone else over Xmas. Depot comp +25%, at highest levels of year. Remember this is America's top discretionary retailer. $HD $LOW $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Exactly this. This ‘store of value’ is partly why Chanel keeps pushing envelope on pricing. Jumbo classic price +12% y/y to €6600 for a freely available & non-limited edition bag.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @deweverj Yes that’s definitely part of it. But it also shows just how iconic the very top luxury brands are for their target demos. Flat would have been a great result for the reasons you mention. +21% is super special

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Hermes has capacity constraints in leather (waitlists on Birkins++) cushioning it. But with over $8 billion in sales, Q4 store-only comp of 21% is just phenomenal. Remember those reports by Bain et al forecasting luxury wouldn't recover till '23 or even '25? $EL $LVMH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Hermes Q4 leaves me speechless. Asia +47% y/y & this is against a non-Covid comparative! Europe only -4%, despite 40% of tourist sales going up in smoke. Top tier iconic luxury is crushing it as wealthy spend. $LVMH $EL $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @lizzie363 They can both be true you know...

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke The US web business was $43bn in the year that just ended & finished Q4 at 14% of total sales. They are more coy about International & Sam's but Flipkart (before the huge Covid boost) was around $5billion. So my guess is $60bn.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @CharlieZvible Haha. Very true. Although this is mostly a history of reacting (dragged kicking & screaming) to $AMZN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This is an issue for all of retail, not just Covid winners. $TJX has struggled with margin for years despite strong comps due to wage rises but is still way below $15/ hour. Needs to be factored into the hopium behind many of the 're-opening' plays.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Walmart release offers clue on latest pressure on margin - lifting average wages to $15/ hour. Shows those 'limited-time' pandemic bonuses were not temporary. Pressure on Covid winners to pay a fairer wage are here to stay. $WMT $TGT $TJX $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Walmart US grew sales $7billion y/y in Q4, almost $6bn of that online. Amazon US grew sales by $22 billion in the same period. $WMT has picked up the pace but $AMZN is still the king of online retail by miles. $TGT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: +8.6% is a good comp number at Walmart. The not-so-good bit is the constant inability to get margin expansion despite the phenomenal comp. That's been the $WMT bugbear for years & will be again in 2021.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This Jan US retail sales report was indeed scorchio nearly +11% y/y. But look closely & yet again Covid winners sparkle: furniture +11%, DIY +19%, sporting goods +23% & of course, web sales +30%. $AMZN $WSM $W $NKE $HD

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This is Sunday data when testing is lowest plus UK testing has fallen post the start of vaccination but -31% on last Sunday is very welcome

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: It’s not all or nothing as most of these pieces claim. COVID has simply put an ongoing trend on steroids. Sure it will revert back some but on balance will those able to work from home do it more often? Almost certainly.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Frito generates latest consistent +5% quarter. 4 points from price. Speaks to strength of portfolio despite what should be ‘bad-4-u’. And $PEP focus on pricing & returns

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: 5.5% points of pricing at Pepsi Cola. Clearly in the US, $PEP & $KO are aligned on maximising pricing in a gently declining category following the tobacco playbook. $MO

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @lizzie363 haha. And it is a 'miracle broth'.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @ConcaveMMT Estée is much more concentrated in luxury which has been a star for several years now. L’Oreal mass & salons have held them back. Within luxury it’s a draw. I’d say $EL greater exposure to US makes it look worse than it is

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: It gets better. Estee plans to report 10-11% sales growth in current Q, a massive acceleration despite Covid headwinds & almost total loss of duty free. Wow. EPS guide is lowballed but that is usual $EL practice.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Estee Q4 flat sales compare to -15% at $LVMH. Pretty clear even when $LVMH reported that their mentions of parallel imports & profitless promos were just excuses for losing share. $EL release makes that graphically clear.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Estee growth led by Estee's highest end brands, especially La Mer as top-tier luxury remains on fire. $EL $PG $LVMH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Wow. For Estee Lauder to deliver 18% skin care sales & 5% perfume sales growth y/y despite Covid & with near zero overseas tourism is just phenomenal. $EL $PG $LVMH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @SehrLangsam2 @JeffMacke ‘Old WS’? :). More seriously though, just look at 2009 charts for most of these names. Uncannily simila. Even more dramatic crashes & then spikes for many.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @SehrLangsam2 Nah legacy matters in China. Also why Burberry is not up there with the others. Op margin yes - but with all three see my earlier tweet. As long as you believe competition will stay super low & inventories super tight for foreseeable future

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Even in China the American trio are running only +40%, +30% & +10% despite lower penetration while European luxury is seeing growth rates of 80%+ due to zero Chinese overseas tourism. $RL $TPR $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Plenty will still hold out for hope for big sales upside at Polo on the other side of Covid. But revenue -20% despite pricing -19% & digital sales only +20%, don't exactly scream soaring brand equity $RL $TPR $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $CPRI & $TPR saw huge gross margins +300bp & +600bp. Both imply this is sustainable. Some caution - zero promos & super tight inventory are NOT here forever. We've seen this movie before - margins soared post 2009 on the exact same effect for many & then crashed.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: That -4% sales number at Coach looks terrific vs -19% at Michael Kors. Neither is great in China but Coach +30% in China also looks way better than +10% at Kors. Kinda why $CPRI only wants to talk Versace Versace Versace. $TPR

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @CourtReagan Yup exactly. In physical retail Amazon’s bark is still way worse than its bite. Whole Foods is a pretty limiting asset. $AMZN made the easy choice like $WMT did with Asda. But in the long haul it isn’t paying off

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Yet again, Whole Foods was dreadful, down 8%. But it's now a rounding error. The $AMZN US online retail business grew +45% y/y to hit an incredible $71 billion in revenues - an amazing $22 billion in new dollars. More than $TGT annual online sales. $WMT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: For once, $AMZN International outshone the US. US nothing to sneeze at but international has stepped up all year, culminating in +50% in Q4, suggesting the franchise benefits boosting the US taking hold in some overseas units too.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Armed by payables, $AMZN lifted quarterly capex by 5X y/y! Q4 capex alone was 20% higher than full year 2019. Ongoing massive capex & staff investments make it nearly impossible for others to keep up. $TGT $WMT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: This $AMZN Q is wowzy. Yes sales growth was fantastic at +42%. But what stands out is working capital. Inventory only +15%, but payables +54%, driving operating cash flow +54% y/y. $WMT $TGT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Clearly a rising luxury tide is floating all boats. And this is an expectations game. But there's clearly a second tier in luxury. Versace's -7% & Choo's -27% look ugly vs +15% at Cartier & +18% at Vuitton. $CPRI

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: So much for ‘temporary’ bonuses. But only the strong can afford it. COVID winners getting stronger in all sorts of ways $LOW $SBUX $AMZN $HD $WSM

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Colgate finished 2020 on a high. Even as pantry-loading is easing industry wide, organic growth hit 8.5%, led by US (both oral care & Hills) & Lat Am. $CL $PG $UN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: A health crisis or an economic crisis, Latin America remains ‘treasure island’ for consumer staples makers. Colgate grew volume despite realising pricing of 9.5% in Q4 $CL $UN $KO $PM

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Oh and BTW, it really helps to control Covid. Greater China +15% & Australia +23% in H1 at Diageo. $DEO

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Strength in US really stands out. In contrast to +12% in US, Europe slumped 10%, as tighter restrictions took a toll on  much higher on-trade exposure than in US. $DEO $BUD $TAP

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Diageo organic sales +1% led by terrific 12% growth in the US offset by declines everywhere else. Demand strong in the US & spirits keep taking share from beer. $DEO $TAP $BUD

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $LVMH premium beauty was weak, -15% after -16% in Q3. However, offering excuses like not participating in promotions or not supplying certain distribution channels =  it lost a lot of share. $EL $PG

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Barring Europe (where spend excluding tourists was very strong), all regions accelerated at $LVMH, with Asia & the US leading. $EL

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $LVMH fashion & leather goods up a terrific 18% in Q4, accelerating on that blow-out +12% number in Q3. On heels of Cartier's +14%. Top tier luxury is on fire. $EL

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @CapitalEdgeNY Yes that’s true. Frito Lay is another master of that

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @RyeNotBerben Yup but it’s still some skill given the periodic growth struggles of so many other parts of their portfolio

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Quarter after quarter, folks love to talk Gillette, Dove or Pampers but it’s Tide & Persil that super consistently deliver for $PG & $UN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: The wizards of detergents have done it yet again. Just how do P&G & Unilever keep growing washing powder 7-8% quarter after quarter! $PG $UN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Gap between top tier luxury & others evident in contrast between Burberry & Richemont. Cartier +25% in Asia in Q4, while Burberry is excited about 11% in the same region. $CPRI $FTCH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Net-a-Porter Q4 sales improved modestly to +4%, but disappointing at Richemont. Brand has become weaker over time & since Richemont took full ownership. Unsurprising that $CFR & Alibaba chose Farfetch for China $FTCH $BABA

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Richemont China Q4 +80% y/y after+ 78% in Q3; no deceleration unlike Tiffany. Europe -20% & US +4% despite sharply lower wholesale = spending by locals in US +20% & Europe +40%(!) $EL $LVMH $CPRI $FTCH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Cartier drove growth at Richemont. Jewelry +14% in Christmas Q after -4% in Q3. +14% will be up there with $LVMH & Hermes. Superbrands still leading luxury sales by a wide margin during pandemic. $EL $CPRI $FTCH

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Richemont strong +5% y/y over Christmas Q despite wholesale -8%. With near-zero tourism, spending by wealthy locals very strong everywhere from Asia to America. $LVMH $EL $CPRI $FTCH #luxury

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Cartier grew +14% y/y over Christmas Q, almost twice what street expected. Strength online & in-store & everywhere except Europe. Even in Europe, with zero tourism & lockdowns, remarkably strong. $LVMH $FTCH $EL #luxury

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @SehrLangsam2 Not a fan of sequential reads here TBH. The few that have reported say the opposite - December was strong after slow November. And y/y reads looked strong in many of the the categories this analysis derides.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Citi Q4 card spend -7% y/y after -10% in Q3; delinquencies charge-offs improved both y/y and q/q $C $JPM $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Gas, apparel, department stores, eating out all dreadful. Electronics too (although $BBY has consistently massively out paced official retail sales). $URBN $M $JWN

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: COVID all over a strong +6% y/y December US retail print. DIY, sporting goods, grocery & of course, web sales. Web +19% y/y after +26% in Nov. $AMZN $HD $LOW $TGT $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $JPM did not build any reserves against credit cards & released some reserves against home. Card delinquencies ticked up modestly sequentially but charge-offs significantly lower both on Q3 and vs last year. $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: $JPM credit card spend continues recovery. Q4 spend down only 3% after -8% in Q3 & -23% in Q2. $XRT

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: @JeffMacke Absolutely. Though I think Mr Market just wants to look through that ‘ever-further’ uptick... Those stocks keep going vertical everyday

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: And also remember, everyone in retail, even apparel, is benefiting from super low promos. They will normalise too.

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Apparel yet again hardest hit by COVID resurgence. This $URBN update shows that while a big one time tick-up will come when things ease, the long term issues haven’t gone anywhere $M $GPS $JWN $RL

name: Rahul Sharma
tweet: Discretionary categories strongest at $TGT. Home leads again. Margins will explode again. Lather. Rinse. Repeat: A COVID Story. $WSM $HD $LOW $BBY
